items.title: Everybody is winging it, all the time.
items.content_html:
I probably suffer a tiny bit from imposter syndrome, so I find it hard to commit myself to consistently write articles (however minimal they might even be). But then again:Â 

So here it goes, below you can find yet another list of resources I have come across on my adventures on the world wide web.
Some of these links I can already scratch from the list âœ”ï¸ğŸ˜Š.

I am still thinking about:

  1. How to best structure posts. One aspect is that alot of these resources are also on other's guides (e.g. see Introduction to smart contract security and hacking), but I don't think it's a big issue. Each of these items is worthy of a blog post, as there is alot of content to cover.
  2. I reckon the Publii theme I've chosen is not the most sensible one from a UX perspective (especially on Mobile), but I'll see how it goes... ğŸ™ˆ

General

  • https://kernel.community/module-0/ (âœ”ï¸->article)

  • https://github.com/Certora/Tutorials + https://certora.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CPD/pages/2916673/Getting+startedÂ 
  • https://entethalliance.github.io/crosschain-interoperability/crosschainsecurityguidelines.html#sec-introduction (âœ”ï¸-> article)
  • DeFi MOOC Lecture 12 Premiere: Practical Smart Contract Security by samczsun
  • CTF's: https://twitter.com/arunim_shukla/status/1532263207146262529?s=20&t=ax0dTGnmYqb8ZrUIdYrDiQÂ 
  • https://start.me/p/QRg5ad/officercia
  • https://github.com/SunWeb3Sec/DeFiHackLabsÂ 

Â 

EVMÂ 
  • https://eth.wiki/en/concepts/evm/ethereum-virtual-machine-(evm)-awesome-listÂ 
  • https://takenobu-hs.github.io/downloads/ethereum_evm_illustrated.pdf (âœ”ï¸->article)
  • https://blog.qtum.org/diving-into-the-ethereum-vm-6e8d5d2f3c30Â 
  • https://consensys.net/blog/blockchain-explained/Â 
  • https://consensys.net/blog/blockchain-explained/want-to-really-understand-blockchain-you-need-to-understand-state/Â 
  • https://media.consensys.net/ever-wonder-how-merkle-trees-work-c2f8b7100ed3Â 

'Everybody is winging it, all the time', I came across this saying a couple of years ago and it resonated with me. It still does, after all these years. A quick search brought me back to the Hacker News post discussing the (seemingly original) Guardian article "Everyone is totally just winging it, all the time".

Photo by David Pupaza on Unsplash.

items.title: DeFi Security Summit 2022 by Stanford
items.content_html:
I came back from a long and refreshing summer holiday, so I haven't had much time to catch up with all the latest security news, but here it goes!

A lazy post pointing to the First Annual DeFi Security Summit (2022). You can find all the recordings on their YouTube channel. Some presentations (in PDF) can be found on their website as well.

Its line-up of speakers is chockful with very knowledgeable folks from the Web3 / DeFi / smart contract security sphere:

  • Mitchell Amador, CEO of Immunefi
  • Kurt Barry, Smart Contract Specialist, MakerDao
  • Emiliano Bonassi, Co-Founder of DeFi Italy
  • Anton Permenev, Founding Partner at ChainSecurity
  • Julien Bouteloup, Founder of Rekt, Blackpool & Stake DAO, Curve Team Member
  • Tarun Chitra, CEO and Co-Founder of Gauntlet
  • Nurit Dor, VP Product at Certora
  • Jared Flatow, VP of Engineering at Compound Labs
  • Emilio Frangella, Â Head of Smart Contracts at AAVE BGD
  • Jesse Tasman, Head of product at Redefine
  • Mudit Gupta, Chief Security Officer at Polygon
  • Hugh Karp, Founder of Nexus Mutual
  • samczsun, Research Partner at Paradigm and White-Hat Hacker
  • GonÃ§alo Sa, Co-Founder and Security Researcher ConsenSys Diligence
  • Mehdi Zerouali, Co-Founder and Director of Sigma Prime
  • Christopher Whinfrey, Co-Founder at Hop
  • Ryan Zarick, Co-Founder and CTO of LayerZero
  • NicolÃ¡s Venturo, Head of Smart Contracts at Balancer Labs
  • Tina Qian, Blockchain Security Engineer at Coinbase
  • Richard Chen, General Partner at 1confirmation
  • Jonathan Alexander, CTO of Openzeppelin
  • Michael George, Director of Product at Certora
  • Joran Honig, Security Researcher & Product Lead at ConsenSys Diligence
  • storm0x, Contributor in Security and Core Development, Yearn Finance
  • Everett Hildenbrandt, CTO of Runtime Verification
  • Kostas Ferles, Principal Scientist at Veridise
  • Layne Haber, Research Lead, Connext
  • Nick Selby, VP, Software Assurance Practice, Trail of Bits
  • Filipe Casal, Cryptography Analyst at Trail of Bits
  • Neville Grech, Security Engineer and Founder of Dedaub
  • Mark Toda, Protocol Engineer, Uniswap Labs
  • Yuchen Lin, Lead Security Engineer, TrustToken
  • Denys Ivanov, Hacken COO
  • David Tarditi, VP of Engineering at CertiK
  • Yoav Weiss, Security Fellow at the Ethereum Foundation
  • Jan Gorzny, Head of L2 Scaling, Quantstamp

Thank youÂ Spencer from Spearbit ğŸ‘‹

items.title: DAO governance attacks, and how to avoid them (az16 crypto)
items.content_html:
A nice coop by Pranav Garimidi, Scott Duke Kominers and Tim Roughgarden:Â  https://a16zcrypto.com/dao-governance-attacks-and-how-to-avoid-them/Â 

From the article:

Many web3 projects embrace permissionless voting using a fungible and tradable native token. Permissionless voting can offer many benefits, from lowering barriers to entry to increasing competition. Token holders can use their tokens to vote on a range of issuesâ€”from simple parameter adjustments to the overhaul of the governance process itself. (For a review of DAO governance, see â€œLightspeed Democracy.â€)Â But permissionless voting is vulnerable to governance attacks, in which an attacker acquires voting power through legitimate means (e.g., buying tokens on the open market) but uses that voting power to manipulate the protocol for the attackerâ€™s own benefit. These attacks are purely â€œin-protocol,â€ which means they canâ€™t be addressed through cryptography. Instead, preventing them requires thoughtful mechanism design. To that end, weâ€™ve developed a framework to help DAOs assess the threat and potentially counter such attacks.Â 

It is an attack which is less prevalent than phishing, but they can be devastating nonetheless (e.g. DAO treasuries getting emptied).

Photo by Andrea Lightfoot on Unsplash

Â

items.title: A Tool for Detecting Metamorphic Smart Contracts by Michael Blau (a16z crypto)
items.content_html:
Michael Blau released his detector for metamorphic smart contracts:Â  https://a16zcrypto.com/metamorphic-smart-contract-detector-tool/

A critical Ethereum security assumption is that smart contract code is immutable and therefore cannot be changed once it is deployed on the blockchain. In practice, some smart contracts can change â€“ even after theyâ€™ve been deployed. With a few clever tricks, you can create metamorphic smart contracts that â€œmetamorphoseâ€ into something else â€“ and by understanding what makes them possible, you can detect them.

Detector tool: https://metamorphic.a16zcrypto.com/Â 
GitHub: https://github.com/a16z/metamorphic-contract-detectorÂ 

Photo by Chan on Unsplash.

az16 crypto (az16 is perhaps not the most ethical VC firm in existence, but then again what company truly is?) also has other great resources:

  • Web3 Weekly newsletter
  • State of Crypto Report (here is the 2022 edition)
  • Other blockchain and cryptocurrency related articles. They also have a section on security and privacy.

Â

items.title: Ethereum Smart Contract Security Best Practices by ConsenSys Diligence
items.content_html:
Never dismiss something published by ConsenSys Diligence, so here you go:

Ethereum Smart Contract Security Best Practices

  • General Philosophy describes the smart contract security mindset
  • Development Recommendations contains examples of good code patterns
  • Known Attacks describes the different classes of vulnerabilities to avoid
  • Security Tools lists tools for improving code quality, and detecting vulnerabilities
  • Bug Bounties List of bug bounties in the ecosystem.

Other practical best practices from SkidsDAO wrt GitHub Actions & DevSecOps can be found here: https://github.com/SkidsDAO/security-policies ğŸ’ª

items.title: The Auditooor Grindset
items.content_html:
The Auditooor Grindset, or a crash course on smart contract auditing for vulnerability researchers by Stephen (@gf_256) from audit firm Zellic.

A slightly biased, hilarious and yet ridiculously informative piece on Web3 auditing: https://blog.zellic.io/2022/02/11/auditor-grindset/ ğŸ™Œ

Photo by Hester Qiang on Unsplash. It's extremely clichÃ©, I admit it ğŸ™ƒ. To make up for it, I've added a great song:

items.title: Sanny's Solana security resources
items.content_html:
I can hardly keep up with all that is going on in the Ethereum security space, let alone the Solana security space...

Cross-posted from CryptoTwitter on the SkidsDAO Discord, here is another treasure trove of Solana security resources. ğŸ‘‡

There are a ton of awesome Solana Security resources out there

From validating accounts to Anchor checks to post-mortems of major hacks

If you want to learn more about auditing smart contracts and exploits on @solana, check out these resources below ğŸ‘‡ğŸ§µ pic.twitter.com/KucjPimqXp

items.title: Â Nascent's Simple Security Toolkit
items.content_html:
The NascentğŸŒ± team shared their collection of practical security-focused guides and checklists for smart contract development:

https://github.com/nascentxyz/simple-security-toolkitÂ 

It covers the following 4 areas:

  1. Development Process
  2. Audit Readiness Checklist
  3. Pre-Launch Security Checklist
  4. Incident Response Plan Template

Additional listening and viewing

Twitter Spaces by Forta discussing the Simple Security Checklist: https://twitter.com/i/spaces/1ZkJzbkrnNDJv?s=20Â 

Simple Security Checklist walkthrough by Nascent's Brock Elmore:

Someone cross-posted this on the Spearbit Discord, and to be honest, this is one of the most practical and hands-on list of resources I have come across.ğŸ”¥

Photo by Max Saeling on Unsplash.

items.title: The Anti-Ape on what's wrong with bridges
items.content_html:
The Anti-Ape posted a great article on today's challenges with cross-chain bridges.

What's wrong with bridges? Perils, Present and Future of Cross-Chain Communication: the road after Layer Zero

It's a very enlightening read, to which I don't have anything remotely useful to add.ğŸ™ƒ

Go read and learn!

Additional reading viewing (via Spearbit ğŸ™Œ)

Understanding Bridge Security with Connext's Arjun Bhuptani

0:00 Intro
1:34 Background
7:15 Current bridge landscape
13:31 The next thing: Optimistic bridge
20:00 Why 30 minute window ? Non-technical ways to mitigate the risk
26:20 Q&A: Veryfing off chain with more conviction
 30:08 Q&A: Centralized wallet integration - transaction valid before the time limit
 33:03 Q&A: Complexity comparisson
40:07 Q&A: Standards accross chains
42:14 Q&A: Bridges as fundamental blocks between nation states
44:16 Q&A: Are you just proving the state of the bridge on one side of the other?
45:44 Q&A: Approach for audit orgs
47:32 Q&A: Recommended training curicculum
51:15 Q&A: Type of hacks:
- implementation hacks (ex. Poly Network)
- complexity of dependencies (ex. Wormhole hack)
- compromise root of trust (ex. Ronin)
55:24 Q&A: Technical risks vs social engineering/corparate risks
58:37 Wrap up

Photo by Arny Mogensen on Unsplash

Â

items.content_html:
